mxCell.value: Welcome to MyBudgetCoach. I'm so proud of you for taking this first step to get started budgeting, or to try a new budgeting method. My name is Celia and I'm going to guide you through this process.

<<Budget>>

Budgeting can feel overwhelming. It can be hard to get started and even harder to stick with it. I'm here to help break it down into manageable pieces and encourage you along the way.

<<Budget>>

I'm thrilled that you are feeling excited and confident about budgeting. Let's dive right in and get you going.

I'm a real person who LOVES to budget and talk about budgets. But my virtual persona is not nearly as good a listener as real life me. My avatar is going to be a great companion to walk you through the budget set up and some budget habits, but if you need a real live listening ear please feel free to book a time for us to meet.
Not sure

<<Budget>>

How are you feeling about budgeting today?

Nervous
mindset = nervous

Excited
mindset = excited
highlight: zoom_link
Tell me more about who I'd be messaging

<<Budget>>

Here's where you can book a time to chat with me in real life. This would be an additional cost per hour.
I'm ready
My budget categories are already set up

<<Budget>>

The first thing I like to do when setting up a new budget is look at how we want to organize the categories. There are a couple of great options and I'll tell you about each and then let you choose.

Then I'll help you build your budget with categories that fit your life. This is what makes personal finance personal.

<<Budget>>

One option is to organize by frequency of each expense. Monthly bills, frequent/ongoing spending, and non-monthly expenses.

This option is great for people new to budgeting who need to make sure they have the money they need ready when they need it. It also can allow you to focus on smaller amounts of money at a time while you learn.

<<Budget>>

Which do you want to try?

<<Budget>>

You want to organize by frequency, great. I'll help you get that set up.
Let's do it

<<Budget>> 

You want to organize by type. Awesome. I'll help you get that set up. 

Each time you choose an area below it will auto create a group in your budget so only click on areas you want to include (though you can delete them if you change your mind). 

Once you've clicked each one you need you can click "I'm done" to move on.

<<Budget>>

When setting up by frequency I like 3 main sections.
1 - Monthly Bills
2 - Monthly "Live" Spending
3 - Non-Monthly Spending

We will work on each of these sections one at a time.

<<Budget>>

Let's start with monthly bills. I include in this category anything that comes out typically once each month for a predictable amount. It might vary a bit like an electric bill but you can make a reasonable guess at the amount and due date.
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Choose a theme that applies to your life.

<<Budget>>

Here's a quick food category group. You could expand on it by separating groceries into weekly amounts, or by separating dining out into different purposes like socializing vs I forgot to plan ahead vs. I just like coffee, ok.
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

I tried to streamline this but if you want more detail, like separate categories for water, electric and heat please add those. Also if you don't escrow property taxes or insurance or if you have an HOA, you'll need to add those categories. You could also think about if there are any seasonal expenses related to your housing.

My "Big Expenses" category is intended for things like furniture, appliances, repairs etc. "Household Goods" is smaller stuff like toilet paper or a screwdriver.

<<Budget>>

Here are some categories you might need for a car.

<<Budget>>

Don't forget to prioritize joy in your budget. Here are some ideas but please edit them to fit what brings you joy.
Back to choices

<<Budget>><br style="border-color: var(--border-color);"><br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">Here are some categories you might need for kids. But every family is different so I'm sure you have some edits to make here.
Back to choices
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

Here's a start on technology categories. You might choose to separate the subscriptions out into individual categories if that works better for you.
Back to choices

<<Budget>>

These are some boring adult things that cost money so you should probably prepare for them
I tested it out

<<Budget>>

The budget screen can show 1 month at a time or several. Test that out by clicking the calendar icons. Personally I like one month most of the time and two when we're coming up to a month rollover.
move_to: calendar_icons
By the way...

<<Budget>>

While it's set to multiple months you can use the months bar here to choose which months are displayed. You might choose this month and last right at the beginning of a month or this month and next toward the end of a month.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget." Currently that amount is zero because we haven't told it about any accounts yet, but when we do I'll come back and explain it further.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

First, I'll give you a quick tour of the budget screen. This is where you will be able to see how much money is available for each expense. It's the core of your budgeting experience.

<<Budget>>

This next bit might feel a bit dry but it's important so you know where to find things later.

<<Budget>>

The main feature on this screen is the budget table. Think of it as a digital envelope system where dollars are waiting to be spent on specific things.

<<Budget>>

The Category column is a list of the things people spend money on. Deciding what to include here is a good way to personalize your budget and feel some ownership.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where we initially place dollars in their envelopes. Each month this amount will show how much was put in in that month.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows what was actually spent out of the budgeted dollars. These numbers will be generated as transactions are entered in accounts and categorized.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what is available to spend. If it's negative and red, the category is overspent. If the amount is black, that's what is left.

<<Budget>>

Even the best budgeters sometimes overspend. That's ok, the next step is to adjust the budget to account for this overspending, that way there's no risk of over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at the three dots next to the category header. This gives visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a category group name in this column (Like Usual Expenses), an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Let's try that. Add a category called "Unicorn Treats".
Magic Wand
I got this

<<Budget>>

Would you like me to wave my magic wand and you edit from there or do you want me to show you a list of ideas and you can add the ones you need manually?

<<Budget>>

Bibbiti Bobbiti Boo

<<Budget>>

I'm so confident you'll rock this. First edit the name of "usual expenses" to "monthly bills". Then use my list and your knowledge of your bills to add categories to the monthly bills group. Also add a second group for monthly bills - wants (more on that in a minute).

Here's my list of ideas:
Rent/Mortgage
Utilities (one category or separate)
Phone
Internet
TV/Streaming
Car Payment
Car Insurance
Debt (one category or a few)
Subscriptions
Gym or other memberships

<<Budget>>

We're off to a great start. Now it's your turn. Go through the list and delete ones that don't apply to your life and add in anything I forgot. Remember this is just for monthly bills at the moment.

I condensed things like water, electric and heat bills into one category for utilities. If you prefer those separated out please go ahead and separate them. Same for things like subscriptions.

<<Budget>>

Great work. I hope that feels good to capture that information in an organized way. Next we'll move on to "Live" spending.
Practice budget here we come
I'm ready for my real budget

<<Budget>>

So in summary, here's the plan

<<Accounts>>

Did you know you can change the name of your budget? Simply click the current name in the highlighted box and select "rename budget". Let's call this one "Fantasy Land" so we remember not to use it for real budgeting later.
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

Nice! Now I'll just walk you through the accounts screen so you know where things are. If you need a refresher later, you can click the three dots in the lower right of this box to reset any conversation to go through it again.
move_to: center_screen

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account "Treasure Hoard", select the cash account type and then enter a balance of $576.35.

When you click "create" it will take you to that account screen.

<<Accounts>>

Let's add a practice account for our fantasy land. Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

In MyBudgetCoach we base our budget on the money we currently have, not an estimate of what we'll earn in a month. That makes the accounts section a key part of the budget because it tracks how much money we have available.

This same process for adding transactions will work in credit card accounts or really any account type. Think of it like an old school balancing of your checkbook, but much faster and less math.

Account set up

<<Budget>>

...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...

<<Budget>>

There's a quick survey that lets you provide me with feedback so I can be the best version of my virtual self.

User Survey after Tutorial

<<Budget>>

You are doing so great. The key to experiencing budgeting joy and success is consistency so keep coming back and working with your budget. I'll pop up every now and then to offer guidance. You can also check out the various conversations I've written about different topics you might need support with.

<<Budget>>

If you need some extra encouragement or have specific questions don't hesitate to book a video call with me (budget for it first) or shoot me a message in the message center.

<<Budget>>

Remember, the key to long term success is sticking with it.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
move_to: zoom_link

<<Budget>>

You already have a budget. Awesome. 

I'll offer a few quick ideas for optional ways you could edit it and then we'll move on.

<<Budget>>

I recommend grouping your budget by frequency of expenses if you're new to budgeting. By that I mean monthly fixed bills as one group. Frequent "live" spending like groceries or dining out as another group. Then less frequent non-monthly expenses as a third group.

Within each of those groups if you have many categories it can be helpful to split into a group of wants and a group of needs.

This helps make it easy to see what you need to budget for in what order as money comes in.

<<Budget>>

If money is less tight and your reason for budgeting is better awareness of your spending then organizing by thematic groups works really well.

So you'd have a group for house, car, kids, food and so on. Within each group you might want to put things in order of priority, like monthly car payment and gas towards the top and saving for the next car further down.

<<Budget>>

If these ideas have made you rethink things you can drag and drop your categories to rearrange them.

<<Budget>>

One final tip before we move on to setting up your accounts.

It can be hard to remember specific things like exactly how much Netflix costs each month or how much you need to budget monthly for an annual membership. 

If you hover over a category name there's a small paper icon. Click that and you can add notes. I like to put the amount, due date if applicable and any other details here. This way I'm not always having to look things up when I'm trying to focus on budgeting.

Before we move over to the account screen please take some time if you haven't already to go through the categories I suggested and delete those that don't apply to you and add in any that I forgot.

<<Budget>>

Another option is to organize by type of expense, grouping house expenses together, car expenses etc. 

This option is great for people who are budgeting to help get a better idea where their money is going. Maybe you always have enough but want to gain some insight and optimize.

<<Accounts>>

You have three options for keeping accounts up to date in MyBudgetCoach. One is simply entering transactions manually. Another is downloading a file from your bank and importing that. The third option is using a third party syncing software (SimpleFIN). For the moment we're going to stick with manual entry while we learn (and because fantasy land doesn't have banks to import from).

<<Budget>>

If my face is in the way while you're learning try out different month displays to help. It's also possible to close the avatar window while you're working and then pick up where we left off by selecting the conversation from the left sidebar.

<<Budget>>

Now that you've made your list I want you to sort it into wants and needs. You can do this by just clicking and dragging the categories into the wants group. We're still only focusing on fixed monthly bills but some of those might be more necessary than others.

I am not here to judge your priorities (and unless we meet on zoom I can't even see them) but it will make the budgeting part easier if you've already made some decisions about what's most important.

You also might want to drag the bills so they're in roughly chronological order, things due earlier in the month towards the top and so on.

<<Budget>>

When I say "Live" spending I mean any time you're an active participant in the spending. This could be buying gas at the pump, ordering take out on your phone or an Amazon order from your home computer.

<<Budget>>

So let's think about all the things you spend money on during most months. We will save things that are less frequent than monthly for our next groups. 

Once again we will be sorting our categories into needs and wants to help us with our budgeting later.

<<Budget>>

Once again I'm going to invite you to sort these into needs and wants. 

Some will be obvious, others you might not be sure where they fit for you. Go with your gut and adjust later, nothing is set in stone.

<<Budget>>

Go ahead and delete what you don't need and add anything I forgot.

<<Budget>>

This last section is one that is often overlooked in traditional budgeting since we're so used to looking at monthly expenses. But there are many expenses that don't occur every month. Instead of letting them sneak up on us we're going to plan for them.

<<Budget>>

These will be our Non-Monthly expenses. Some of them are boring like car registration and others are fun like travel. We will sort these into needs and wants too. One rule I have for myself for these kinds of categories is "would I be willing to go into debt for this if it came around and I wasn't prepared for it?" If the answer is yes (like the car repairs) then it's a need and I make sure that my monthly budget can support saving for my non-monthly needs before I spend on monthly wants.

Nicely done! Just go ahead and sort those if you haven't already and then your budget is done. Ok, it's never really done. There will always be new things to add and expenses you don't have anymore. But this is a great start and it can grow and evolve with you over time.

<<Budget>>

We set up the two sides of the budget, the categories and the accounts, and we practiced tracking some spending. Youre making such strong progress.

<<Budget>>

Now we get to practice the actual budgeting part of the process. This might feel very different to what you expect budgeting to look like. The main difference is that youre only going to budget with money that you have right now instead of predicting how much money you will have for the month.

<<Budget>>

Basically we will take our current cash on hand and allocate that money to various categories depending on how we plan to spend it.

<<Budget>>

Here at the top it shows us how much money we have to budget.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Would you like an analogy or an example?
I'll give you a chance to read both if you want.

<<Budget>>

Imagine you live 50 years ago, when digital banking wasnt the norm.  Youre doing your budgeting with a pile of cash and a bunch of envelopes. You put that cash into different envelopes so you know how much is for groceries and how much is for the electric bill. You cant put cash you dont have yet in envelopes.

<<Budget>>

Lets say I have $500 in the bank right now and its the middle of the month. I probably dont need to use any of that money for rent because I already paid that this month. So instead of looking at a generic month budget I look ahead at whats coming up in real life.

<<Budget>>

Perhaps my phone bill is $120 and due in 3 days. I budget $120 to that. That leaves $380. I know Im going out for a friends birthday this weekend so I put $80 in that category, leaving $300. Typically I spend $150/week on groceries and $50 on gas, so I budget those amounts. That leaves $100 and I dont have any other immediate needs in the next week before I get another paycheck so I budget the $100 to my travel savings.

<<Budget>>

Then when I get my next paycheck I once again look at bills coming up, regular expenses like groceries, irregular things based on the reality of my next few weeks, and then looking ahead further if I can.
Nope, I got it

<<Budget>>

Do you want to circle back to hear the other?
I took a break and I'm ready for the real thing
Break time

<<Budget>>

All done with the practice budget. Are you ready to try it with your real life? This might be a great time to step away for a bit and let the new ideas sink in. Don't be gone too long, I'll be here waiting.

<<Budget>>

If you wanted to make a plan for upcoming paychecks you might also jot down notes on the outside of the envelope like car payment, $200, 25th so that when you get paid you remember how much to put in. But that doesnt mean you can pay the car payment before you put the cash in the envelope.

<<Budget>>

By keeping the money in separate envelopes you avoid accidentally spending the electric bill money on groceries. It also lets you easily see at a glance what you can safely spend on dining out or clothes without shorting yourself elsewhere.
If I have time, add more examples and support here upon request. OR add a zoom call prompt (or both)

<<Budget>>

I want you to look at your money that you have available and lets make some choices about what that money needs to do.

<<Budget>>

If at any point in this process you run out of money, stop budgeting, hit the Im done button and Ill talk you through the next steps.
Keep going
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You want to think about when you are getting paid next and start with any bills that have due dates between now and when you get paid. Fill those in with the amounts needed.
Keep going
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Next,  look at your calendar for the time period until your next expected income and think about anything that is coming up that costs money. That might be a doctors appointment or a birthday party or a haircut. Fill those in. Make a guess about the amount if it can vary.
There's still more money
I'm done

<<Budget>>

You will also need to put money into the categories for things that happen often, most commonly these are groceries and gas but your budget might include other frequent expenses. Put money in all of these. But you dont need to put in a whole month worth, just enough until you get paid again.
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Youve accounted for all your immediate needs and still have money left to budget. Thats awesome. Ill give you a few things to think about so that we can make sure all that money is safely in budget categories. 

Deciding what the money is for before spending it is a really important step in having a successful budget. I've saved the "I'm done" option for the end of these suggestions so you can click through them all and make an informed choice with the rest of your money.

<<Budget>>

Ok, did you budget exactly to zero? If not, go ahead and make a quick adjustment. 

Specifically, if "to budget" has a few dollars left go ahead and put exactly that amount in a future bill, savings goal or fun money or something. 

If youve gone a bit into the negative then adjust a category so it has a bit less and "to budget" is back up to zero.

<<Budget>>

Nicely done, now, if you had to stop before you covered your needs thats important information for you. It means you might have to delay some needs or get creative until youre paid again. 

If you met all your needs then you can feel comfortable spending those funds, but be sure to check the budget if you spend on things you hadnt planned on.

<<Budget>>

Is some of the remaining money because youd already been saving up for specific things like an upcoming car repair, vacation or other large expense? Budget funds to those categories based on what youd already planned to do with that money.

<<Budget>>

Are there times of the month when your bills cluster and things get tight with that paycheck? You could consider budgeting some money to those bills ahead of time so its not so tight then.

<<Budget>>

Are there longer term expenses that you could start saving for, like annual memberships, seasonal clothing shopping, planting a garden or holidays?
I'm done

<<Budget>>

Do you have debt you can work on paying down? Or big savings goals like retirement that you want to work on bulking up?

Now go ahead and budget the remainder of your money.

<<Budget>>

Now that all your money is budgeted I want to show you something. Look at the number next to for budget in the far left column.
move_to: for_budget_accounts

<<Budget>>

Now look at the number under balance at the top of the current month. These two numbers should match. If they don't, first check if your "to budget" number is zero. If it's not zero adjust your budget so it is zero.
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

These numbers match because all the money you have in your accounts is in the balance column in the budget. Any changes to accounts (adding transactions) will also change the budget by the same amount, so these numbers stay aligned and you can trust your budget.

<<Budget>>

Now, I want you to go away for a couple days (set a reminder if you need one) and come back once there are a few transactions in your bank account. We want at least 3 things to practice with but not more than 10. That way its manageable for both of us. See you soon.
Budget theory and check to budget amount
Budgeting Dollars
Working with real transactions, overspending

Lets start in your checking account. First find the spot in your real life checking account that matches the starting balance you entered in your MyBudgetCoach account.

Now youll hit add new and add each transaction that has occurred since that starting balance.

<<Accounts>>

Click add new. 
Choose the date the spending happened. 
Type in a payee, that means where you spent the money, like Costco or Amazon.

<<Budget>>

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>
